TEXT:
Chief Complaint: respiratory distress
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
    Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity gangrene,
   underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by
   perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for ascites and
   bradycardia, and is now transferred to MICU for management of
   hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   .
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).
   - MAPs > 60
   - SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 50 mg IV x 1 upon arrival to floor
   - vanc/zosyn; consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
   - sputum, urine, blood, stool cultures
   - would consider pulling R subclav
   - check bladder pressure q6h
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Also intubated [**Date range (1) 3633**] on
   surgery for hypotension.
   - placed on pressure control because of high PIPs on AC
   - vanc/zosyn as above
   - will place a-line for ABGs
   - will consider therapeutic para to reduce intra-abdominal pressures
   and improve respiratory mechanics
   .
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   .
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if BPs stable
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   .
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - HD likely today
   - renal reccs
   .
   # FEN: IVFs / replete lytes prn / regular diet
   # PPX: PPI, heparin SQ, bowel regimen
   # ACCESS: PIV
   # CODE:  Full, discussed

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a diagnosis of acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia. He has a history of smoking and has developed pneumonia during hospitalization.
2. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient has sepsis syndrome with a positive blood culture and a diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). He has also developed leukocytosis, tachycardia, and decreased venous return due to ascites.
3. PVD/Left Brachial to Radial Bypass/Right 4th PIP Osteomyelitis: The patient has a history of peripheral vascular disease and has undergone a left brachial to radial bypass. He has also developed right 4th PIP osteomyelitis.
4. HCV Cirrhosis/Liver Mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US concerning for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). He has a history of HCV treatment at a previous hospital.
5. ESRD: The patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is on hemodialysis (HD) three times a week.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and acidemia can worsen, leading to further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient's sepsis syndrome can progress, leading to further hypotension, organ dysfunction, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. PVD/Left Brachial to Radial Bypass/Right 4th PIP Osteomyelitis: The patient's peripheral vascular disease can worsen, leading to further complications such as limb ischemia or gangrene.
4. HCV Cirrhosis/Liver Mass: The patient's liver cirrhosis and liver mass can worsen, leading to further complications such as liver failure, portal hypertension, or HCC.
5. ESRD: The patient's ESRD can worsen, leading to further complications such as uremic syndrome, electrolyte imbalances, or cardiovascular disease.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and optimize respiratory therapy to improve lung function.
2. Administer antibiotics and antifungals to treat sepsis and SBP.
3. Monitor and manage ascites and liver function to prevent further complications.
4. Continue hemodialysis and monitor kidney function to prevent further complications.
5. Monitor and manage peripheral vascular disease and osteomyelitis to prevent further complications.
6. Consider liver transplantation or palliative care for patients with HCV cirrhosis and liver mass.
7. Monitor and manage electrolyte imbalances and acid-base status to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]. He developed perioperative MI, and was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient has multiple comorbidities, including sepsis, hypotension, respiratory failure, PVD, and liver disease. He has a significant risk of developing complications, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient has developed sepsis, with multiple sources of infection, including SBP, R subclavian, L HD line, PNA, and urosepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has developed respiratory failure, likely due to new L pleural effusion and productive cough.
3. PVD: The patient has PVD, which is complicated by left brachial to radial bypass and right 4th PIP osteomyelitis.
4. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites, with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for HCC.
5. ESRD: The patient has ESRD, requiring qMWF HD.

The patient's current condition is critical, with:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 90-115/40-70 mmHg, requiring pressors.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient requires mechanical ventilation, with a PCV setting of 23/10 and PEEP of 10/50%.
3. Distended abdomen: The patient has a distended abdomen, with soft, +BS, and coarse BS.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a prolonged PT/PTT/INR, indicating coagulopathy.

The patient's laboratory results show:

1. WBC: 17.3 K/uL
2. Hct: 27.3%
3. Cr: 4.0 mg/dL
4. Lactate: 1.0 mmol/L
5. Troponin-T: 3.64 ng/mL

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continue Vanc/Zosyn for possible SBP, PNA, and line infection.
2. Albumin PRN, may need restart of pressors.
3. Resp failure felt in part due to ascites/hepatic hydrothorax, CXR improved, will attempt to decrease vent settings as tolerated.
4. Consider further imaging while in-house, including MRI with contrast, contraindicated due to ESRD.
5. Renal will start CVVH today.

The patient is at high risk of developing complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and is at risk of developing further cardiac complications.
2. Infection: The patient has multiple sources of infection, and is at risk of developing further infections.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has developed respiratory failure, and is at risk of further deterioration.
4. Liver failure: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites, and is at risk of developing further liver complications.
5. Renal failure: The patient has ESRD, and is at risk of further renal deterioration.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical history. The patient has been experiencing fever, with a current temperature of 102.4°F, and has been receiving antibiotics, including Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn). The patient's vital signs are unstable, with a heart rate of 105 beats per minute, blood pressure of 94/51 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. The patient is receiving respiratory support with a ventilator and oxygen therapy.

The patient has a multi-lumen catheter and a dialysis catheter in place, and is receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's laboratory results show acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 4.0 mg/dL, and electrolyte imbalances, including hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and hypotension are consistent with sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and treatment.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine level of 4.0 mg/dL indicates acute kidney injury, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and increased risk of mortality.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 100% indicate respiratory failure, which requires close monitoring and intervention.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may indicate cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
5. Electrolyte Imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances, including hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia, can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and laboratory results suggest the presence of an infection, which requires prompt recognition and treatment to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes or complications.
2. Administer antibiotics as prescribed and consider adding additional antibiotics if the patient's condition does not improve.
3. Continue to provide respiratory support and consider adjusting the ventilator settings as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and administer replacement therapy as necessary.
5. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to evaluate the patient's cardiac status and provide guidance on treatment.
6. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to evaluate the patient's kidney function and provide guidance on treatment.

Chief Complaint: respiratory distress
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /

   HPI:
    Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity gangrene,
   underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by
   perioperative MI (cards thought it was NSTEMI [**2-17**] demand). Pt  was
   transferred to medicine for ascites and bradycardia, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.
   24 Hour Events:
   Albumin x1. Therapeutic paracentesis (1.8L) which improved ventilation
   and oxygenation (and reduced bladder pressures). Inotropes not
   required. CXR with L pleural effusion. ABG c/w acute repiratory
   acidosis. BiPap not tolerated, so intubated yesterday at 8PM. PCV for
   high PIPs.

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted to the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure. He has a complex medical history, including recent perioperative MI, left brachial to radial bypass, and upper extremity gangrene. He developed ascites and bradycardia, and was transferred to the MICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is severe, with:

* Respiratory failure: hypoxic on floor, hypercapneic on arrival to unit, and intubated after failing trial of bipap
* Sepsis/hypotension: meets SIRS criteria, positive for SBP on tap, and other potential sources of infection include pneumonia, lines, skin cellulitis, and UTI
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: graft not usable for ABGs, and patient has R BKA and L AKA
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: cirrhosis with ascites, hypoechoic liver lesion on US concerning for HCC, and normal AFP
* ESRD: last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis/hypotension: continued risk of sepsis, hypotension, and organ dysfunction
2. Respiratory failure: continued risk of respiratory acidosis, hypercapnia, and need for mechanical ventilation
3. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: risk of graft failure, infection, and limb loss
4. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: risk of liver failure, bleeding, and HCC progression
5. ESRD: risk of acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalances, and need for further dialysis

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor and manage sepsis/hypotension with IV antibiotics, fluids, and vasopressors as needed
2. Maintain respiratory support with mechanical ventilation and consider therapeutic paracentesis to reduce intra-abdominal pressures
3. Continue to manage PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis with antibiotics and consider surgical intervention if necessary
4. Monitor liver function and consider further imaging to assess liver mass and potential HCC progression
5. Continue ESRD management with HD and monitor for acute kidney injury and electrolyte imbalances

Next steps:

1. Review and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary
2. Consider therapeutic paracentesis to reduce intra-abdominal pressures
3. Continue to monitor respiratory function and adjust ventilator settings as necessary
4. Review and adjust liver function tests and consider further imaging to assess liver mass and potential HCC progression
5. Continue ESRD management with HD and monitor for acute kidney injury and electrolyte imbalances

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

Patient's Chief Complaint: Respiratory distress

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

Key findings:

* The patient has developed new ascites after being told he had cleared his Hep C years ago.
* He has a significant alcohol history, but quit drinking approximately 21 years ago.
* He has undergone multiple procedures, including a 4L paracentesis, and has developed a L pleural effusion.
* He has been experiencing worsening respiratory distress, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation.
* He has a fever of 102.4°F and is receiving antibiotics for suspected sepsis.
* He has a history of cardiac arrest and has undergone cardiac catheterization.

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures suggest sepsis. The source of infection is unclear, but may be related to the subclavian catheter, HD line, or urosepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may be related to the new L pleural effusion, productive cough, or underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and cardiac catheterization suggests a high risk of cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.
* Liver complications: The patient's cirrhosis and liver mass may be related to his HCV infection and may lead to complications such as liver failure, ascites, and portal hypertension.
* Renal complications: The patient's ESRD may lead to complications such as acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalances, and fluid overload.

Plan:

* Continue antibiotics for suspected sepsis and monitor for signs of septic shock.
* Manage respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and adjust settings as needed.
* Monitor cardiac status and adjust medication as needed to prevent cardiac complications.
* Continue to manage liver and renal complications with lactulose, albumin, and IV fluids as needed.
* Consider further imaging and testing to determine the cause of the patient's liver mass and ascites.

   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.

   PCV vent overnight. R IJ placed yesterday afternoon but went to
   sub-clavian on CXR and was removed without complication.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient, a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, s/p perioperative MI, and PVD, was admitted to the ICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure. He underwent left brachial to radial bypass on January 12, 2021, complicated by perioperative MI. He was transferred to the ICU from the medicine service due to worsening respiratory failure and hypotension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PCV mode. His oxygen saturation is 99%, and his respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute.
* Hypotension: His blood pressure is 101/51 mmHg, and he is receiving vasopressors.
* Sepsis: He has a fever curve that has improved, and his leukocytosis is mildly increased. Sources of sepsis include SBP, urosepsis, and possible R subclavian or L HD line infection.
* Liver disease: He has cirrhosis and ascites with a 4L tap on January 13, 2021, associated with hypotension and NSTEMI. He has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for HCC.
* Renal failure: He is on a qMWF HD schedule and will start CVVH today.
* Cardiovascular disease: He has a history of CAD and s/p perioperative MI.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure
* Liver failure
* Renal failure
* Cardiovascular instability
* Gastrointestinal bleeding

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Management of sepsis with antibiotics and vasopressors
* Mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* CVVH for renal replacement therapy
* Lactulose for liver disease
* GI recs for liver disease
* Renal recs for ESRD
* Cardiovascular recs for CAD and s/p perioperative MI.

I will continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust his plan of care as necessary to ensure his safety and optimal outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass, which was complicated by perioperative MI. He is currently in the ICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Fever (103.9°F)
* Leukocytosis (19.1 K/uL)
* Hypotension (BP: 101/51 mmHg)
* Respiratory failure (requiring mechanical ventilation)
* Left pleural effusion (resolved after therapeutic paracentesis)
* Chronic kidney disease (ESRD)
* HCV cirrhosis
* Liver mass (1.8 cm hypoechoic lesion on US)
* Ascites (with 4L tap on [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI)

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 10.4-19.1 K/uL
* Hct: 26.8-33.7%
* Plt: 252-295 K/uL
* Cr: 3.5-4.2 mg/dL
* TropT: 2.90-3.64 ng/mL
* TCO2: 24-29 mmHg
* Glucose: 75-185 mg/dL
* Other labs: abnormal results for PT/PTT/INR, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T, ALT/AST, Alk Phos/T Bili, Differential-Neuts, Lactic Acid, LDH, Ca++, Mg++, PO4

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue vanc/zosyn (started last night)
* Consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
* Sputum, urine, blood, stool cultures
* Lighten sedation
* Reduce set rate to 20
* Decrease PEEP to 10
* Daily CXR, monitor for recurrence of pleural effusion and repeat paracentesis if necessary
* Continue lactulose
* Liver c/s recs
* When stable, consider further imaging while in-house (MRI with contrast contraindicated due to ESRD)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis/hypotension: continued risk of infection and organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure: continued risk of respiratory distress and failure
* Chronic kidney disease (ESRD): continued risk of kidney failure and electrolyte imbalances
* HCV cirrhosis: continued risk of liver failure and bleeding
* Liver mass: continued risk of liver cancer and bleeding
* Ascites: continued risk of fluid overload and bleeding
* Respiratory failure: continued risk of respiratory distress and failure

The patient's current condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Cardiac dysfunction and heart failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass, which was complicated by perioperative MI. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: He is on PCV vent support with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 99%, and his ABG shows a pH of 7.29, PCO2 of 49 mmHg, and PO2 of 23 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular status: He has a MAP of 101 mmHg and a heart rate of 104 bpm. His CVP is 12 mmHg, and his blood pressure is 101/51 mmHg.
* Renal status: He has ESRD and is on a qMWF HD schedule. He is currently on CVVH.
* Infectious disease: He has a fever of 103.9°F, and his WBC count is 10.4 K/uL. He has been diagnosed with sepsis and has been treated with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. He has also been prescribed linezolid as a prophylactic measure.
* Liver function: He has cirrhosis and ascites, and has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, which is concerning for HCC. He has been prescribed lactulose and is awaiting further imaging.
* Other medical conditions: He has a history of PVD, CAD, and DM.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and he may require further ventilatory support to maintain adequate oxygenation.
* Cardiac failure: The patient's heart rate and blood pressure suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac failure, particularly given his history of CAD and PVD.
* Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and current CVVH therapy suggest that he may be at risk for further renal deterioration.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver cirrhosis and ascites suggest that he may be at risk for liver failure, particularly given his history of HCV treatment.
* GI complications: The patient's history of PVD and CAD suggests that he may be at risk for GI complications, such as bleeding or perforation.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue ventilatory support with PCV vent mode and adjust FiO2 and PEEP as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely, and consider adjusting his medications or providing additional support as necessary.
* Continue CVVH therapy and monitor the patient's renal function closely.
* Monitor the patient's liver function closely, and consider further imaging or treatment as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's GI status closely, and consider further treatment or prophylaxis as necessary.
* Consider adding linezolid to the patient's antibiotic regimen if his WBC count continues to rise.
* Consider further imaging or treatment for the patient's liver lesion.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, and consider adjusting his medications or providing additional support as necessary.

   s/p perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity
   gangrene, underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]
   complicated by perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for
   ascites and bradycardia, and is now transferred to MICU for management
   of hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.

   PCV vent overnight. R IJ placed yesterday afternoon but went to
   sub-clavian on CXR and was removed without complication.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and recent perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]. He developed perioperative MI and was transferred to medicine for comorbidities and is now in the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is complicated by sepsis, respiratory failure, and renal failure. He has a fever-free period of 24 hours, but his leukocytosis is mildly increased from 17 to 19 overnight. His sources of sepsis include SBP (diagnosed on [**2111-1-23**] paracentesis), urosepsis (urine cx +ve for >100K GNR), and possible R subclavian/L HD line and PNA (productive of sputum). He also has a new L pleural effusion between [**1-19**] and [**1-23**] CXR, which has resolved after therapeutic paracentesis overnight.

The patient's INR is increasing, likely due to nutrition and SBP, and he has a history of HCV treatment at [**Hospital1 12**]. He has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for HCC. He is on lactulose and will have repeat US in 3 months.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to new L pleural effusion and possible pulmonary edema and pneumonia. His renal failure is managed with CVVH, which has been started.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to SBP, urosepsis, and possible R subclavian/L HD line and PNA. He requires continued antibiotics, including vancomycin and Zosyn, and close monitoring for signs of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to new L pleural effusion, pulmonary edema, and pneumonia. He requires continued mechanical ventilation, with a goal of reducing FIO2 and switching to PSV tomorrow.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is managed with CVVH, which has been started. He requires close monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to sepsis, volume overload, and cardiac dysfunction. He requires close monitoring of his blood pressure and volume status.
5. UTI: The patient's UTI is likely due to E. coli, and he requires continued antibiotics, including vancomycin and Zosyn.
6. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient's HCV cirrhosis and liver mass require close monitoring, including repeat US in 3 months. He may require further imaging, such as MRI with contrast, in the future.
7. ESRD: The patient's ESRD requires close monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels. He requires ongoing dialysis, including CVVH.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his complex medical conditions, including sepsis, respiratory failure, renal failure, hypotension, UTI, HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass, and ESRD.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L
   paracentesis.
   - cont to weane vent
   - vanc/zosyn
   - will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce
   intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics
   - SBT
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with GNRs.
   - MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 25 mg IV bolus
   - vanc/zosyn; consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
   - sputum, urine, blood, stool cultures
   - will attempt to resite CVL, place a-line
   - check bladder pressure q6h
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH today
   - renal reccs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: TFs
   Glycemic Control:

   Multi Lumen - [**2111-1-23**] 07:44 PM

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass complicated by perioperative MI. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis. The patient's current condition is complicated by respiratory failure, sepsis, and multiple potential sources of infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation. Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging due to underlying lung disease and pleural effusions.
2. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient meets SIRS criteria and has multiple potential sources of infection, including pneumonia, lines, skin, and UTI. Management includes antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, and consideration of vasopressors.
3. PVD/Left Brachial to Radial Bypass/Right 4th PIP Osteomyelitis: The patient has a history of PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass complicated by perioperative MI. He has a right 4th PIP osteomyelitis and may require further vascular reccs.
4. HCV Cirrhosis/Liver Mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion concerning for HCC. Further monitoring and repeat ultrasound in 3 months are planned.
5. CAD s/ MI: The patient has a history of CAD and s/p perioperative MI. He requires continued ASA, Plavix, and statin therapy.
6. ESRD: The patient has ESRD and requires ongoing dialysis. CVVH is planned for today.

The patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and management by a multidisciplinary team to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on 1/12. He developed perioperative MI and was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and suspected sepsis. The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and peritoneal cavity as a likely source of infection. He has multiple potential sources of infection, including pneumonia, lines, skin, and UTI. The patient is also experiencing respiratory failure, PVD, and liver disease.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's suspected sepsis is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and treatment. The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and leukocytosis are indicative of sepsis, and the positive SBP on tap and productive sputum suggest a likely source of infection.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia are likely exacerbated by his large abdomen, pleural effusions, and muscular weakness from critical illness. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are necessary to manage his respiratory failure.
3. PVD: The patient's PVD is a chronic condition that may worsen with time. The patient's right 4th PIP osteomyelitis and R BKA and L AKA are potential complications of PVD.
4. HCV Cirrhosis/Liver Mass: The patient's liver cirrhosis and ascites are associated with hypotension and NSTEMI. The 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US is concerning for HCC. Close monitoring and repeat US in 3 months are necessary to monitor the liver mass.
5. CAD s/ MI: The patient's demand ischemia peri-operatively and history of CAD s/ MI make him at risk for further cardiac complications.
6. ESRD: The patient's ESRD requires ongoing management with HD and CVVH.
7. Liver Disease: The patient's liver disease may worsen with time, and close monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage his condition.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: The patient's TFs suggest that he may require nutritional support.
2. Glycemic Control: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, and close monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage his hyperglycemia.
3. Lines: The patient has multiple lines, including a multi-lumen line and a dialysis catheter, which require close monitoring for complications.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient is at risk for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP, and prophylactic measures are necessary to prevent these complications.
5. Code Status: The patient's code status is full code, indicating that he is willing to accept all life-sustaining treatments.

Disposition:

The patient requires ongoing management in the MICU to manage his multiple medical complications. Close monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L
   paracentesis.
   - cont to wean vent
   - vanc. will change zosyn to meropenem given resp failure
   - will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce
   intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics- currently
   bladder pressures 15
   - SBT
   - attempt volume off for improved oxygenation via CVVH
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with Klebsiella.
   - MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 25 mg IV bolus
   - antibiotics as above; consider linezolid if decompensates given
   history of VRE
   - sputum, blood cx pending
   - check bladder pressure q12
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH today- attempt fluid off as tolerated
   - renal reccs

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He underwent left brachial to radial bypass on January 12, 2021, complicated by perioperative MI. He was transferred to the ICU for management of hypotension and suspected sepsis. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, and blood pressure of 107/55 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 99% and ABG showing acute respiratory acidosis. His fluid status is unstable, with a fluid balance of -917 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and troponin levels. His blood cultures are pending, and his urine culture shows growth of Klebsiella pneumoniae.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient meets SIRS criteria and has a positive blood culture for Klebsiella pneumoniae. He also has a history of pneumonia, lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skin (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained after Foley placement).
3. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient has a history of PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass. He also has a history of right 4th PIP osteomyelitis.
4. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites with a 4L tap on January 13, 2021, associated with hypotension and NSTEMI. He has a history of HCV treatment and a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US on January 20, 2020, concerning for HCC.
5. CAD s/ MI: The patient has a history of CAD and MI.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient's septicemia may worsen, and he may require further antibiotics and fluid management.
3. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's PVD may worsen, and he may require further vascular reccs.
4. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient's liver mass may worsen, and he may require further treatment.
5. CAD s/ MI: The patient's CAD may worsen, and he may require further cardiac reccs.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor the patient's respiratory status.
2. Continue antibiotics and fluid management for sepsis/hypotension.
3. Monitor the patient's PVD and consider further vascular reccs if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's liver mass and consider further treatment if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's CAD and consider further cardiac reccs if necessary.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L
   paracentesis.
   - cont to weane vent
   - vanc. will change zosyn to meropenem given resp failure
   - will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce
   intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics
   - SBT
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with Klebsiella.
   - MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 25 mg IV bolus
   - antibiotics as above; consider linezolid if decompensates given
   history of VRE
   - sputum, urine, blood, stool cultures
   - will attempt to resite CVL, place a-line
   - check bladder pressure q6h
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH today
   - renal reccs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities, is being managed in the ICU for hypotension, sepsis, and respiratory failure. The patient's condition is complex, and several potential medical complications can arise. Some of the key concerns include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has met SIRS criteria, and a positive blood culture indicates a high risk of sepsis. The source of infection is likely to be peritoneal cavity, but other potential sources include pneumonia, line infections, skin infections, and UTI.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has a poor respiratory status, with acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia. The large abdomen, pleural effusions, and muscular weakness may be contributing to the respiratory failure.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and the MAP is less than 60 mmHg, indicating a high risk of hypotension. The decreased venous return due to ascites may be contributing to the hypotension.
4. HCV cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites, and a liver mass is concerning for HCC. The patient has a history of HCV treatment and is at risk for liver failure.
5. PVD and left brachial to radial bypass: The patient has a history of PVD and has undergone a left brachial to radial bypass. The graft site may be at risk for infection.
6. CAD s/p MI: The patient has a history of CAD and has undergone a perioperative MI. The patient is at risk for demand ischemia.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Respiration: Weaning from the ventilator, and considering repeat therapeutic paracentesis to reduce intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics.
2. Sepsis: Administering antibiotics, including meropenem, and considering linezolid if the patient decompensates. Sputum, urine, blood, and stool cultures will be sent.
3. Hypotension: Maintaining MAPs above 60 mmHg and SVO2 above 70%. Albumin boluses may be necessary to maintain volume status.
4. HCV cirrhosis: Monitoring liver function and considering paracentesis if bladder pressure increases. Lactulose may be necessary to manage ascites.
5. PVD and left brachial to radial bypass: Monitoring the graft site for signs of infection and considering vascular recs.
6. CAD s/p MI: Continuing ASA, Plavix, and statin therapy to manage demand ischemia.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, hypotension, and liver failure. Close monitoring and management of these conditions are necessary to improve the patient's outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and s/p perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]. Post-operatively, he developed hypotension and respiratory failure, requiring transfer to the MICU.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypotension, requiring pressors
* Respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation
* Possible sepsis, with pending CX data guidance for antibiotic therapy
* Bladder pressure of 15 mmHg, requiring monitoring
* Severe PVD, with left brachial to radial bypass and R BKA, L AKA
* HCV cirrhosis, with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for HCC
* CAD s/ MI, with demand ischemia peri-operatively
* ESRD, with last HD on [**2111-1-21**] and MWF schedule

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction, shock, and death
* Respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis
* Hypotension, which can lead to organ hypoperfusion, ischemia, and death
* Bladder pressure, which can lead to urinary retention, urinary tract infection, and bladder rupture
* Severe PVD, which can lead to limb ischemia, gangrene, and amputation
* HCV cirrhosis, which can lead to liver failure, portal hypertension, and esophageal varices
* CAD s/ MI, which can lead to recurrent ischemia, infarction, and cardiac arrest
* ESRD, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and cardiovascular complications

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Removing volume with CVVHD
* Vanc and meropenem pending CX data guidance for antibiotic therapy
* SBT daily
* Considering repeat therapeutic paracentesis if needed to improve respiratory mechanics
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis, including fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea
* Managing hypotension with pressors and fluids
* Monitoring bladder pressure and considering repeat therapeutic paracentesis if needed
* Managing severe PVD with left brachial to radial bypass and R BKA, L AKA
* Monitoring for signs of HCV cirrhosis, including ascites, encephalopathy, and variceal bleeding
* Managing CAD s/ MI with ASA, plavix, and statin
* Managing ESRD with MWF schedule and CVVH

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and a recent perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**].

Current Status:

* The patient is hypotensive, with a blood pressure of 87/45 mmHg, and is requiring pressors.
* He has respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation, and is being weaned.
* He has sepsis, with a positive SBP on tap, and is being treated with antibiotics.
* He has PVD, with a left brachial to radial bypass graft, and is at risk for graft failure.
* He has HCV cirrhosis, with a liver mass and ascites, and is at risk for liver failure.
* He has CAD, with a recent MI, and is at risk for demand ischemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Sepsis: The patient's positive SBP on tap and sepsis workup indicate a high risk of sepsis-related complications, including organ failure, septic shock, and death.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not adequately treated, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
* Graft failure: The patient's PVD and left brachial to radial bypass graft put him at risk for graft failure, which could lead to limb loss and other complications.
* Liver failure: The patient's HCV cirrhosis and liver mass put him at risk for liver failure, which could lead to increased mortality and morbidity.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's CAD and recent MI put him at risk for cardiac complications, including demand ischemia, arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.
* Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and recent CVVH treatment put him at risk for renal failure, which could lead to increased mortality and morbidity.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure, respiratory status, and sepsis workup to ensure adequate treatment.
* Wean the patient off pressors and mechanical ventilation as tolerated.
* Consider repeat therapeutic paracentesis to improve respiratory mechanics.
* Monitor the patient's liver function and consider repeat ultrasound in 3 months to assess the liver mass.
* Continue treatment for CAD, including ASA, Plavix, and statin.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis schedule as necessary.
* Consider repeat stress testing to assess for demand ischemia.
* Monitor the patient's overall condition and adjust treatment plans as necessary to prevent complications.

   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now

   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on

   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, who was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. He developed perioperative MI and was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and suspected sepsis. The patient has respiratory failure, with acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia, and is intubated. He also has sepsis, with positive SBP on tap, and multiple sources of infection, including pneumonia, lines, skin, and UTI. The patient has chronic kidney disease and is on hemodialysis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if not properly managed, leading to further acidosis, hypoxia, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt and aggressive management to prevent further deterioration.
3. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Liver disease: The patient's HCV cirrhosis and liver mass may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further liver dysfunction, portal hypertension, and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Cardiovascular disease: The patient's CAD and perioperative MI may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiac complications, including heart failure, arrhythmias, and potentially life-threatening events.
6. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient's PVD may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further limb ischemia, gangrene, and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Infections: The patient's multiple sources of infection, including pneumonia, lines, skin, and UTI, may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further sepsis, organ dysfunction, and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis aggressively, with prompt administration of antibiotics and source control measures.
3. Monitor the patient's chronic kidney disease closely and adjust hemodialysis settings as necessary to maintain adequate fluid and electrolyte balance.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function closely and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further liver dysfunction.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further cardiac complications.
6. Monitor the patient's peripheral vascular status closely and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further limb ischemia and gangrene.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infections closely and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further sepsis and organ dysfunction.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and a recent perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on 1/12. He was transferred to the MICU due to hypotension and suspected sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Able to extubate after volume removal, doing well post-extubation.
* Sepsis/Hypotension: Able to wean off pressors, SBP on tap on 1/23. Other possibilities include pneumonia, CVL, skin, and UTI.
* Severe PVD: Left brachial to radial bypass, R BKA, L AKA.
* HCV Cirrhosis/Liver Mass: 4L tap on 1/13 associated with hypotension and NSTEMI, 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US on 12/20 concerning for HCC.
* CAD s/ MI: Demand ischemia peri-operatively, continuing ASA, Plavix, and statin.
* Cellulitis: Continuing Vanc.
* ESRD: Last HD on 1/21, MWF schedule, CVVH possibly, renal following.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 17.3, 19.1, 13.8, 9.9
* Hct: 27.3, 26.8, 28.2, 31.7
* Plt: 290, 252, 250, 201
* Cr: 4.0, 3.9, 4.2, 4.3
* TropT: 3.64, 3.30
* TCO2: 24, 22
* Glucose: 111, 119, 75, 87

The patient's medical complications include:

* Sepsis/hypotension
* Respiratory failure
* Severe PVD
* HCV cirrhosis/liver mass
* CAD s/ MI
* Cellulitis
* ESRD

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia
* CVL
* Skin infection
* UTI
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Ischemic events

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition closely to prevent or manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU patient who was extubated and is doing well on nasal cannula oxygen. The patient was previously on pressors and CVVH, but was taken off both due to improvement in blood pressure. However, the patient's blood pressure dropped at around 8 PM, and 25 grams of albumin were given without significant improvement. The patient was restarted on levophed and attempted to wean down, with no mental status changes noted.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature (T) 36.7°C, heart rate (HR) 108 bpm, blood pressure (BP) 120/66 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) 100%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 8 mmHg.

The patient's fluid balance is as follows: total input 2,339 mL, total output 3,408 mL, resulting in a net loss of 1,069 mL. The patient's respiratory support includes a face tent and PSV/SBT mode on the ventilator.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 17.3-10.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.0 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 290-277 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 4.0-2.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 3.64-3.30 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 4.0 g/dL
* LDH: 141 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 8.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 3.5 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show a CXR with heart enlargement, patchy opacities at both lung bases, and possible superadded infection.

The patient's microbiology results show a respiratory culture with sparse growth of commensal respiratory flora, with mixed bacterial types and yeast. The patient has chronic renal failure, chronic kidney disease, and acidosis.

The patient's plan includes ICU care, nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Hypotension due to septic shock or chronic kidney disease
* Respiratory failure due to chronic lung disease or superadded infection
* Sepsis due to the presence of yeast and mixed bacterial types in the respiratory culture
* Renal failure exacerbation due to inadequate fluid management or chronic kidney disease
* Electrolyte imbalances due to acidosis or chronic kidney disease
* Infection due to the presence of commensal respiratory flora in the respiratory culture
* Cardiovascular instability due to chronic kidney disease or septic shock.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]. He developed perioperative MI and PVD and was transferred to the ICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient's vital signs remain stable, with a heart rate of 108 bpm, blood pressure of 120/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is still on nasal cannula and has been extubated.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, with a decrease in his respiratory rate and a stable oxygen saturation. He is still on oxygen therapy, with a FiO2 of 70%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 17.3, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 277 K/uL. His creatinine level is 3.6 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 22 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show a heart that is enlarged, with patchy opacities at both lung bases indicating volume loss and possible superadded infection.

The patient's microbiology results show a mixed bacterial flora, including yeast and gram-negative rods, in his respiratory culture.

The patient's plan includes continued antibiotic therapy for urosepsis, maintenance of MAPs > 60, and SVO2 > 70%. He will also undergo daily bladder pressures and will be monitored for signs of sepsis and hypotension.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has urosepsis and a positive blood culture, which increases his risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia, which can worsen his respiratory status.
3. Hypotension: The patient has a history of hypotension and is at risk of developing further episodes.
4. Liver failure: The patient has cirrhosis and a liver mass, which can lead to liver failure.
5. Kidney failure: The patient has ESRD and is at risk of developing further kidney damage.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has CAD and a history of MI, which can lead to further cardiovascular complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

   Patient is critically ill<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery on January 12th. He was transferred to the MICU due to hypotension and suspected sepsis.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 102 bpm, blood pressure of 91/72 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on nasal cannula. He has a central venous pressure of 5 mmHg and is receiving norepinephrine infusion at 0.05 mcg/kg/min.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 10.2 K/uL
* Platelet count: 277 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mEq/L
* Glucose: 94 mg/dL
* Albumin: 4.0 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L

The patient has multiple medical conditions, including sepsis, hypotension, respiratory failure, severe PVD, HCV cirrhosis, liver mass, CAD with demand ischemia, and ESRD. He is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and anticoagulants.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's suspected sepsis may lead to further organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, cardiovascular instability, and renal failure.
2. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension may require further adjustments to his vasopressor therapy and may increase the risk of organ dysfunction.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his underlying lung disease is not managed effectively.
4. PVD: The patient's severe PVD may lead to further limb ischemia and potential amputation.
5. HCV cirrhosis: The patient's HCV cirrhosis may lead to further liver dysfunction and potential liver failure.
6. CAD: The patient's CAD may lead to further cardiovascular instability and potential myocardial infarction.
7. ESRD: The patient's ESRD may lead to further renal dysfunction and potential dialysis dependence.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple complex medical conditions, requiring close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and optimize his care.

   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent

   decompensates given history of VRE

   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R

   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on 2111-01-12, complicated by perioperative MI. He is now transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient was hypoxic on the floor and hypercapneic on arrival to the unit. He was intubated and extubated this morning. He has a large abdomen, pleural effusions, and muscular weakness from critical illness, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure.
* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient has urosepsis and a positive SBP on tap on 2111-01-23. He is being treated with vancomycin and meropenem, and his blood pressure is being monitored.
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient has a history of PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass. He also has right 4th PIP osteomyelitis. He will not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites with a 4L tap on 2111-01-13 associated with hypotension and NSTEMI. He has a history of HCV treatment at Hospital1 12. He has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US 2110-01-20 concerning for HCC.
* CAD s/ MI: The patient has a history of CAD and had a perioperative MI.
* ESRD: The patient has ESRD and is on a qMWF schedule for hemodialysis.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98.1°F)
* Heart rate: 95 bpm (86-113 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 91/37 mmHg (52-112/81 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 10 breaths per minute (3-25 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Central venous pressure: 5 mmHg (5-5 mmHg)

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 19.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 269 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mg/dL
* Glucose: 119 mg/dL

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continued treatment with vancomycin and meropenem for urosepsis
* Monitoring of blood pressure and central venous pressure
* Daily bladder pressures
* Volume off on CVVH goal -1 to -2L/day
* Consideration of linezolid if the patient decompensates given his history of VRE
* Follow-up sputum and blood cultures
* Vascular recs
* Liver recs
* Albumin PRN for volume expansion
* Lactulose
* Renal recs

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his large abdomen, pleural effusions, and muscular weakness from critical illness.
* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient's sepsis and hypotension may worsen due to his urosepsis and positive SBP on tap.
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's PVD and left brachial to radial bypass may lead to further complications, such as graft failure or infection.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient's cirrhosis and liver mass may lead to further complications, such as liver failure or HCC.
* CAD s/ MI: The patient's CAD and perioperative MI may lead to further complications, such as demand ischemia or reinfarction.
* ESRD: The patient's ESRD may lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances or uremic syndrome.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, who underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery complicated by perioperative MI and is now admitted to the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient's current condition is:

* Hypotensive, requiring norepinephrine infusion
* Uroseptic, with a positive fluid culture for SBP
* Respiratory failure, with acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia
* PVD with a left brachial to radial bypass graft
* HCV cirrhosis with ascites and a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion concerning for HCC
* CAD with a history of perioperative MI
* ESRD on a qMWF HD schedule

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient's hypotension and positive fluid culture for SBP increase the risk of further decompensation and potential organ failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and acidemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further respiratory compromise.
* PVD/graft failure: The patient's PVD and history of perioperative MI increase the risk of graft failure and potential limb loss.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient's cirrhosis and liver lesion may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further liver dysfunction and potential liver failure.
* CAD/MI: The patient's history of perioperative MI and CAD increase the risk of further cardiac events, including MI and cardiac arrest.
* ESRD: The patient's ESRD may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further kidney dysfunction and potential end-stage renal disease.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management in the MICU, including:

* Maintenance of MAPs > 60 and SVO2 > 70%
* Continuation of meropenem for urosepsis
* Daily bladder pressures and fluid management
* Albumin replacement for volume expansion
* Diagnostic para to evaluate for possible SBP with resistant organisms or VRE
* Weaning of levophed as tolerated
* Recheck of BP and cardiovascular status
* Continuation of ASA, plavix, and statin for CAD
* Renal recs for ESRD
* Liver recs for HCV cirrhosis
* Vascular recs for PVD

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust management accordingly to prevent further decompensation and potential organ failure.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male admitted to the ICU for worsening peripheral vascular disease (PVD), who underwent left brachial to radial bypass on January 12th. The patient has a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), diabetes mellitus (DM), coronary artery disease (CAD), and a recent perioperative myocardial infarction (MI) and peripheral vascular disease.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypotension (BP 115/64 mmHg)
* Respiratory failure (oxygen delivery via nasal cannula)
* Sepsis/hypotension (ESBL Klebsiella from urine)
* Severe PVD (left brachial to radial bypass)
* HCV cirrhosis/liver mass (hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC))
* CAD/MI (demand ischemia peri-operatively)
* Cellulitis (cont Vanc)
* ESRD (MWF schedule, renal following)

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98.1°F)
* Heart rate: 107 bpm (normal range: 86-113 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 115/64 mmHg (normal range: 47-115/15-76 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 19 breaths per minute (normal range: 8-25 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 19.1 x 10^9/L (normal range: 4-11 x 10^9/L)
* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL (normal range: 13.5-17.5 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 269 x 10^9/L (normal range: 150-450 x 10^9/L)
* Creatinine: 3.9 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.1 mg/dL)
* Troponin-T: 3.30 ng/mL (normal range: 0.0-0.04 ng/mL)
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L (normal range: 0.5-2.0 mmol/L)

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing low-dose levo to wean off today
* SBP on tap on January 23rd
* Repeat US in 3 months for liver evaluation
* Repeat dx tap per liver recommendations
* Continuing ASA, Plavix, and statin for CAD/MI
* Continuing Vanc for cellulitis
* MWF schedule for ESRD

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Hypotension-related organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure-related complications (e.g., pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia)
* Liver-related complications (e.g., bleeding, sepsis)
* Cardiovascular-related complications (e.g., arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock)
* Renal-related complications (e.g., acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression)

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.
